repnme.cdata!:
Developing Countries of the Wider Caribbean
            Region - The Wider Caribbean Initiative on Ship Generated
            Waste Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Wider Caribbean Initiative on Ship
            Generated Waste Project was innovative - it was the first
            time that the Bank has been directly concerned with the
            implementation of the International Convention for the
            Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARIPOL 73/78), as well
            as the first time the Bank has worked with the International
            Maritime Organization (IMO). The project, judged as
            satisfactory with a likely sustainability, learned the
            following lessons: a) there was an underestimation of time
            required to reach consensus among the 22 involved countries;
            b) better definition of respective responsibilities for
            supervision and procurement were needed prior to signing; c)
            more intensive involvement of the Bank's legal and
            environmental specialists would have improved preparation;
            d) the IMO's appointment as executing agency imposed a
            barrier between the Bank and the beneficiary countries; e)
            in the absence of a region-wide suitable institution,
            special attention should have been given to the involvement
            of suitable sub-regional institutions; f) when a project
            represents a new area of work for the Bank, a formal
            mid-term review should have been included in the Project
            Document; g) the decision to close was based on the
            Bank's judgement that agreed deadlines were not
            achieved and in the face of the "inability" of the
            IMO to follow agreed procedures and action; and h) the Bank
            should continue to support the efforts of IMO and
            governments to implement and sustain MARPOL 73/78.

728376.trustfund:
TF023410-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF028606-GET-PPA FOR WCISW,TF028653-GET-CARIBBEAN INITIATIVE FOR
            SHIP WASTE

repnme.cdata!:
Developing Countries of the Wider Caribbean
            Region - Wider Caribbean Initiative for Ship-Generated Waste

abstracts.cdata!:
The Wider Caribbean Initiative for Ship
            Generated Solid Wastes Project is conceived as the first
            phase of a longer term process of cleaning up and protecting
            the Caribbean Sea. The objective of this first phase program
            is to provide the basis for ratification and implementation
            of the International Convention for the Prevention of
            Pollution from Ships (MARPOL 73/78) by the Developing
            Countries of the Wider Caribbean Region (DCWCR). The project
            will finance consultant services and their logistical
            support to: 1) assess existing legislation and regulations
            of the DCWCR; 2) identify legal remedies available under
            international agreements to comply with regulations; 3)
            assess existing waste management systems in the DCWCR; 4)
            formulate regional engineering criteria for waste reception
            facilities at the ports; 5) coordinate discussion with
            shipping and cruise lines on reducing waste; 6) develop
            integrated waste management alternatives; 7) develop
            strategies for the integration of collection, treatment and
            disposal of ship-generated waste; 8) assist ports in
            defining the appropriate tariffs for receiving wastes; 9)
            develop proposals to ensure that DCWCR achieves full cost
            recovery of the collection; 10) develop strategies for
            public awareness programs; 11) brief potential donors,
            financing institutions, and nongovernmental organizations on
            the status of MARPOL 73/78; and 12) based on the success of
            the project, develop a strategy for expanding benefits to
            other areas.
